If the player lands on a square the same colour as their token, a chance card is drawn. On some spaces an exam card is drawn. A player cannot move again until an exam question is answered correctly. The first player to travel the board wins.

119707.name: 24 Game Primer Add/Subtract
119707.description: Each card contains two wheels and a target number. Player must pick the wheel that can make the target number. You can add and subtract only. Use all the numbers on each wheel, but use each number only once. Only one wheel works on each card. Each card is worth 1 to 3 points depending on difficulty. The first player to make the target number wins the card. Player with the most cards wins.

119708.description:
Game uses double nine dominoes and has an electronic Chicken Coop hub. Players start with 7, 9, or 11 dominoes depending on the number playing. The first player who has a double nine plays it in the center hub, and the next six dominoes fill in the spaces around the hub to form the chicken legs (if a player cannot match a nine, they draw and play or pass). After that, players match domino ends until a double is played.

When a double is played, the player presses the hub and normal play is suspended until three chicken "toes" are played. The next three dominoes must match the double and are played under the double, one angled to the left, one in the center and one angled to the right (to form the chicken foot). Players who cannot match can draw and play the match, or they must pass. Play continues until the three toes are completed and normal play resumes either on the chicken toes or any of the chicken legs.

Play ends when a player plays their last domino or the game is blocked (because no plays can be made and the "chicken yard" (spare dominoes) is exhausted. The player who gets rid of their dominoes scores 0. The other players count their pips on their remaining dominoes to get their score. A new round then begins. After 10 rounds, player with the lowest score wins.
119708.name: Chicken Coop Dominoes

119709.name: Monkeyshines!
119709.description:
From the box:

Five computerized puzzle games filled with action-packed monkey business! You'll go ape over Monkey Tag, Monkey Chess, Tailspin, Shuteye and Bananas! You have to be agile as four computer-smart monkeys that can run, jump, climb, tease, dive, swing, hop, spin, scamper and cavort over virtually endless patterns of monkey bars.

119710.name: Dynasty!
119710.description:
Samurai is a video game for the Philips Magnavox Odyssey². It is identical to the game Reversi. The game also contains two player mode, gameplay against the computer, as well as a digital timing handicap which allows newcomers to have a better chance in beating grandmaster players in the game.

Source: Wikipedia, "Samurai (Videopac game)", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

119711.name: Football!
119711.description:
From the box:

You captain a team of realistic electronic superstars! Call the signals! There's a full complement of offensive and defensive play options including widely varying running and passing situations. On-screen digital readouts count down the clock and show the score.

119712.name: Baseball!
119712.description:
From the box:

This will take you out to the ball game in the purest sense! The pitcher can throw inside and outside curves! The outfielders can play to a batter's weakness. A batter can hit for a hole in the outfield. On-screen digital readouts show balls, strikes and score!

119713.name: Computer Golf!
119713.description:
From the box:

A nine hole, par 36, electronic golf course for one to four players. Realistic electronic golfers hit long drives and fairway shots! You really walk the course and have true control over backswing, distance, and direction.

119714.name: Invaders from Hyperspace!
119714.description:
From the box:

Swarms of sinister alien space ships materialize and attack outpost solar systems in a remote corner of the United Planets Interstellar Galactic Empire. You'll need lightning reflexes and instantaneous strategic insights to protect all the planets in your two vulnerable solar systems from the invasion fleet!

119715.name: Speedway!/Spin-Out!/Crypto-Logic!
119715.description:
Race is a fairly simple game where you control a car travelling on an infinite straight stretch of road. You start from still, and move the stick up to accelerate, down to decelerate, right and left move the car sideways. The object is to keep driving for as long as possible, without crashing into any of the other cars. If you ever slow to a stop then your car gets run over.

Spin-out is a two-player game, in which each player controls a car around a loop of racetrack. The winner is the one who completes 3 or 15 laps the fastest, there are time penalties for crashing into a wall or spinning when hit by the other car.

Cryptogram is also for two players, one types in a message of up to 14 characters, then hits enter to scramble it. The other player types in what they think it is, and loses points for each incorrect letter, in something like the spirit of hangman.

Source: Wikipedia, "Race - Spin-out - Cryptogram (Videopac game)", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

119717.name: Freedom Fighters!
119717.description:
From the box:

You command a starship of the Earth Federation Rescue Fleet. Your mission is to free your comrades from the Pulsar Empire's deep space confinement crystals. They are guarded by Pulsar warships which attack you with constellations of hunter-killer drone mines.

119718.name: Armored Encounter! / Sub Chase!
119718.description:
Air-Sea War is a two-player game with player one controlling an aeroplane which is constantly moving from the right to the left of the screen while trying to drop bombs onto a boat controlled by player two, which is moving from left to right, and trying to fire missiles up at the plane. Both the bombs and missiles can be controlled after firing. There are also two neutral craft in the water. A point is added for each hit on the enemy, and one is deducted for each hit on a neutral craft, although scores never go negative. The player with the most points at the end of three minutes is the winner.

Battle is also a two-player game, in which each player controls a tank around walls and mines, with the aim being to fire the most shots on your opponent's tank in three minutes, a point is deducted for hitting a mine, but scores never drops below zero. Multiple modes could be chosen with differing layouts of walls, the option of having mines or not and an option of walls absorbing or rebounding shots.

Source: Wikipedia, "Air-Sea War - Battle (Videopac game)", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

119719.name: Showdown in 2100 A.D.
119719.description:
In Gunfighter, a shootout game for the Magnavox Odyssey², two gunfighters face one another across a field filled with trees. In the United States the game was released as Showdown in 2100 A.D.

The object of the game is to shoot the other player's gunfighter. The first player to hit the other gunfighter ten times wins. The trees add some challenge to the game by deflecting bullets fired at them, sometimes even back at the gunfighter who originally fired. At close range it is possible to shoot through the trees. Each gunfighter has six bullets, and more ammunition is hidden in the tree which matches the color of the player's outfit. Each gunfighter can reload at any time by touching the tree where his bullets are hidden.

Source: Wikipedia, "Gunfighter (Videopac game)", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

119720.name: Smithereens!
119720.description:
Stone Sling was one of the games for the Philips Magnavox Odyssey², a console from the 1970s in the 8-bit home video game console era. The game allows for two player simultaneous gameplay where both players have a fortress as well as a catapult used to fire each other. With each hit the fortress' size decreases by a bit. However sometimes if your aim is off, the catapult will miss the fortress and instead hit one of the opposing soldiers. In the United States it was sold under the title Smithereens!.

Source: Wikipedia, "Stone Sling (Videopac game)", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

119721.name: Les 1000 Bornes de l'Histoire
119721.description:
A Mille Bornes variant in which players must score maximum points by bringing together the largest number of periods in the history of France and most of the possible themes of each period.

Draw a card to your hand, play or discard.

The game ends when one player has placed a series of six cards and he managed to shoot down six cards in his hand. The game also ends if no cards remaining in the deck is playable.
Each series reported scores up to 40 points, 10 bonus points triggering endgame, foul play by 10 points.
The winner is the first totaling 500 points after several parties.

119722.name: Les 1000 Bornes des Animaux
119722.description:
A Mille Bornes variant with animals in much the same way as its predecessor. Here are ranging animals instead of kilometers!

Draw a card to your hand, play or discard.

The game ends when one player has placed a series of six cards and he managed to shoot down six cards in his hand. The game also ends if no cards remaining in the deck is playable.
Each series reported scores up to 40 points, 10 bonus points triggering endgame, foul play by 10 points.
The winner is the first totaling 500 points after several parties.

119723.name: Les 1000 Bornes des Inventions
119723.description:
A Mille Bornes variant in which players must score maximum points by collecting the most inventions possible.

Draw a card to your hand, play or discard.

The game ends when one player has placed a series of six cards and he managed to shoot down six cards in his hand. The game also ends if no cards remaining in the deck is playable.
Each series reported scores up to 40 points, 10 bonus points triggering endgame, foul play by 10 points.
The winner is the first totaling 500 points after several parties

119724.name: Les 1000 Bornes des Mots
119724.description:
A Mille Bornes variant in which players must form the sentences with the words on the cards.

The goal is to make sentences with these words. Since we Dujardin, add a few cards of attack and defense. The fire becomes red misspelling, and the green light a dictionary.

Draw a card to your hand, play or discard.

The game ends when one player has placed a series of six cards and he managed to shoot down six cards in his hand. The game also ends if no cards remaining in the deck is playable.
Each series reported scores up to 40 points, 10 bonus points triggering endgame, foul play by 10 points.
The winner is the first totaling 500 points after several parties

119725.name: Les 1000 Bornes Olympiques
119725.description:
A Mille Bornes variant in which players must score maximum points by just replacing the miles by sports, by the lights of the pitfalls and "Long live the Olympics!"

Draw a card to your hand, play or discard.

The game ends when one player has placed a series of six cards and he managed to shoot down six cards in his hand. The game also ends if no cards remaining in the deck is playable.
Each series reported scores up to 40 points, 10 bonus points triggering endgame, foul play by 10 points.
The winner is the first totaling 500 points after several parties.

119726.name: Les 1000 Bornes de la Bible
119726.description:
A Mille Bornes variant in which players must score maximum points by exposing the maximum cards in as many rounds as possible (there are 12 series: the beginnings, the Patriarchs, Moses, To the promised land, the time of the Kingdom, the time exile, renewal, a new prophet, Jesus' encounters, the messages of Jesus, the passion, the early Christians). Each set contains 6 cards.

Draw a card to your hand, play or discard.

The game ends when one player has placed a series of six cards and he managed to shoot down six cards in his hand. The game also ends if no cards remaining in the deck is playable.
Each series reported scores up to 40 points, 10 bonus points triggering endgame, foul play by 10 points.
The winner is the first totaling 500 points after several parties.

119727.name: Les 1000 Bornes de la Nature
119727.description:
A Mille Bornes variant in which players must score maximum points by exposing the maximum cards in as many rounds as possible (there are 11 series: mushrooms, flowers, evergreens, deciduous trees, shrubs and fruit trees, herbs and spices, exotic plants, plants water, industrial plants, poisonous plants, medicinal plants).

Draw a card to your hand, play or discard.

The game ends when one player has placed a series of six cards and he managed to shoot down six cards in his hand. The game also ends if no cards remaining in the deck is playable.
Each series reported scores up to 40 points, 10 bonus points triggering endgame, foul play by 10 points.
The winner is the first totaling 500 points after several parties

119728.name: Victoria
119728.description:
Publisher blurb:

Welcome to Victoria, a roleplaying game of suspense, action and intrigue, set in the Victorian era, a time characterized by breathtaking bravery, overwhelming hardship and earth-shattering events, the effects of which can still be felt today.

This is the world of Charles Darwin, Florence Nightingale and Charles Babbage, steam power, workhouses, and chimney sweeps, Sherlock Holmes, Jekyll and Hyde, Stanley and Livingstone, The Charge of the Light Brigade and Jack the Ripper.

This is the world of Victoria.

In the game players take on the roll of anything from a thief living by their wits in Bethnal Green’s deadly back alleys to a hero embroiled in the struggle between shadowy groups for control of the largest empire the world has ever known.

119729.name: Jackal: Treasure Island
boardgameexpansion: Jackal
119729.description:
Expansion for "Blue" edition of Jackal

Adds some new rules, new tiles, new accessories such as boat, cannonballs, big gold coin. New tiles have different effects, and it is possible to use them instead of no effect tiles from basic jackal, or together to create big island to discover. Much more variants of islands with this extension.

119730.name: Mon premier 1000 Bornes
119730.description:
"My first Mille Bornes" in English
Multiple rules for different ages.

A simple scenario speaks to all children the road to school!
The whole family moves the car to go from home to school. But beware, you must arrive before the school principal, if not the school doors will close before you even have time to enter the yard!
Game introduces for children the world of the road: signs, traffic lights etc.

119731.name: Dragón (Número 1 - Abr 1993)
119731.description:
Spanish Dragón Magazine Issue #1
Some articles published in this journal have been taken from the English magazine
Dragon (Issue 164 - Dec 1990)
Dragon (Issue 182 - Jun 1992)
Dragon (Issue 183 - Jul 1992)
Dragon (Issue 188 - Dec 1992)
and Dungeon
Dungeon (Issue 27 - Jan 1991)
Dungeon (Issue 39 - Jan 1993).
Summary in spanish:

ARTÍCULOS:

ESTO ES ROL, NO ROLLO, por George T. Young
Como puede ayudar el maestro a los jugadores.
SE AMABLE CON TU ARBITRO, por Stewart Robertson
Un buen jugador no es el que mejor hace rodar los dados.
ROLES PARA JUGADORES DE ROL, por David Wilder
Modos en que ayudar al master y animar el juego.
QUÉ TIENES EN SUS BOLSILLOS?, por Ed Greenwood
O como puede un ladrón hallar aventura en la siguiente bolsa.
EL BESTIARIO DEL DREGÓN, por Gregory Detwiler
Dos adiciones, poco recomendables, a la familia Dragonil!

MÓDULOS:

MASTODONTE, por Roger E. Moore (para AD&D, niveles 4-7)
Hay un goblin que tiene el mejor y más mortífero juguete.
LA FUENTE DE LA SALUD, por Ann Dupuis (para D&D, nivel 1)
Un sorbo de su agua sana, pero llegar hasta ella puede matarte.

RELATO:

EL NIDO DEL GRIFO, por Ardath Mayhar
Ser madre siempre es difícil, y si se es una madre grifo...

SECCIONES:

EL RUGIDO DEL DRAGÓN
Habla nuestro director
PLUMAS ENVENENADAS
Las misivas que nos llegan
EL ORÁCULO DE LOS DIOSES
Consultorio para jugadores
+3 EN CARISMA
Contactos entre los lectores
EL ZONO DE LANKHMAR
Una bolsa de compraventa
EL HERALDO DE LA CORTE
Anuncios clubs, jornadas, fanzines
UNA ACLARACION...
Cuatro palabras sobre la Guía del Juego de Rol.
CHACOTAS Y COQUITOS
Un alto en el camino, para reír antes de seguir.
RUNAS Y PERGAMINOS
Los libros del juego de rol
JAQUE MATE
El mercado de los juegos
CON PIES DE PLOMO
Novedades en figuras para jugar
BYTES Y MAZMORRAS
Los otros juegos, los electrónicos
LA TIRADA FINAL
También habla nuestro redactor jefe
ESPECIAL
Poster / Mapa de la Fuente de la Salud (un terreno de juego ideal para tus figuras... o tu imaginación.

Algunos artículos editados en esta revista han sido extraídos de la revista inglesa
Dragon (Issue 164 - Dec 1990)
Dragon (Issue 182 - Jun 1992)
Dragon (Issue 183 - Jul 1992)
Dragon (Issue 188 - Dec 1992)
de la
Dungeon (Issue 27 - Jan 1991)
Dungeon (Issue 39 - Jan 1993)

119732.name: Bescherelle le Jeu
119732.description:
The game of Bescherelle is a game designed for fun around the traps and conjugations of the French language.

TO goal is to conjugate a verb or answer a question in French.
Players may get magical potions to transform into superheroes and defence against attacks from your opponents!

Award-winning and recommended by the Ministry of Culture and Communication of France.

119733.name: Jeu du Paf
119733.description:
A kind of new version of Game of Goose with the theme of
P.A.F. is (French Audiovisual Landscape)

On the squares with usual pitfalls, you will pass small tests and answer the questions.

Otherwise, the rules of the Game of the Goose are unchanged.

119734.name: Dragón (Número 23 – Ene 1996)
rpg: Lord of the Rings Roleplaying Game
119734.description:
Spanish Dragón Magazine Issue #23
Some articles published in this journal have been taken from the English magazine Dungeon (Issue 56 - Nov 1995) and Dragon (Issue 223 - Nov 1995).
Summary in spanish:

ARTÍCULOS:

LOS NUEVE SEÑORES, por McComb
El Desconocido hasta ahora "quién es quién" de los insondables abismos de Planescape.
PRIMAL RAGE, por Rob Lettsy
Directamente de la pantalla del ordenador a ti compendio de monstruos.
Cuidado con ellos!
EL MONSTRUO ADECUADO PARA LA AVENTURA ADECUADA, por Gregory W. Detwiler
Los clásicos horrores de la Llamada de Cthulhuse ponen al día: normas de utilización para Guardianes de los Arcanos inteligentes.
DRAGON DICE: CARTAS DE EFECTOS MAGICOS, por Lester Smith
Nuevas reglas y nuevas cartas para mejorar tus partidas del juego que más priva en la actualidad: Dragón Dice.
GEN CON 95, por Joaquim Dorca
Relato de lo acaecido en la Convención de Rol para aquellos que no pudieron estar presentes.

MÓDULOS:

GRAVES CIRCUNSTANCIAS, por Bill Slavicsek (para AD&D Universo Sol Oscuro, niveles 5-7)
Aunque parezca mentira, en Athas las cosas se pueden hacer mucho más cuesta arriba de lo que están por naturaleza.
AL OTRO LADO, por Jordi Cabau (para el Señor de los Anillos)
Si siempre quisiste saber lo que se siente en la piel de los malos, ésta es la oportunidad para sufrir a gusto.

SECCIONES:

EL RUGIDO DEL DRAGÓN
Ni las cartas ni los dados arredran a nuestro bravo director
PLUMAS ENVENENADAS
Parabienes, comunicados, opiniones y hasta tirones de orejas
EL ORÁCULO DE LOS DIOSES
La ración de sabiduría que engrasa tus partidas
+3 EN CARISMA
Del llamamiento al desafío, pasando por la petición de ayuda y el ruego desesperado.
EL HERALDO DE LA CORTE
Clubes, roleros, fanzines y jornadas con fundamento
EL ZONO DE LANKHMAR
Chalaneos y compraventas para una economía de subsistencia lúdica.
RUNAS Y PERGAMINOS
La particular librería de los lectores de DRAGON
CON PIES DE PLOMO
Nuevas figuras, nuevas sensaciones
JAQUE MATE
Lo que alegra nuestras partidas y hace peligrar a nuestro bolsillo
BYTES Y MAZMORRAS
Escapamos a la influencia de la Liga Anti PlayStation
LA TIRADA FINAL
Y como dice cierto cerdito tartamudo: Eso es... eso es... eso es todo amigos!

Algunos artículos editados en esta revista han sido extraídos de la revista inglesa magazine Dungeon (Issue 56 - Nov 1995) y Dragon (Issue 223 - Nov 1995).

119735.description:
The Builder is a new Action card for Jerusalem.

Just add the card to the basic Action card deck to play with it.

When you play this Action card, place it under one of your squire who's inside one area of the game board. That Squire will have a Horse for the rest of the game. After the first step of phase 3 (The Tower of David), the Squire with the Horse may be moved anywhere on the game board (with the exception of blocked areas by Barons).
Note 1: If an opponent plays "Turncoat", the opponent takes also the Horse!
Note 2: If that squire is removed from the game after a War event or he's killed (the new Assassin card), the card is removed too.
119735.name: Jerusalem: The Horse
boardgameexpansion: Jerusalem

119736.name: One Piece: Grand Battle
videogamehonor: 2005 Game Critics Best Fighting Game of the Year Nominee
119736.description:
One Piece: Grand Battle! is a fighting game made in Japan based on the Anime and Manga series One Piece. It is the fourth game in the Grand Battle series.
There are four different modes in the game: Grand Battle, a one-player/two player mode that features unlocked fighters and stages; Story Mode, a mode that follows every character through the story; Training, a testing mode to test one's skill; and Tourney, a tournament mode that allows to select a character and fight in it and a baseball mode

Source: Wikipedia, "One Piece: Grand Battle!", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

From back of box
7 Colourful stages full of crazy gimmicks. Pick up and use objects to fight your foes.
Choose from 16 one of a kind wacky pirates and 32 support characters - each with more than 20 regular moves.

119738.name: Le Rouge et le Noir
119738.description:
The game includes 5000 questions on French/foreign literature and the French language. It plays like 'snake and ladders', without shortcuts, though.

The board consists of several squares with different topics like: works, authors, expression, citations, parenthesis etc.
Also some special square like:

Bomb Box: Opponents choose the theme. If the player answers correctly, he continues, otherwise it returns to the starting point.
Boom Box: The player chooses the theme. If he answers correctly, he continues, otherwise it returns to the starting point.
Box blank page: Player advances with as many questions indicated on card if he answered said questions correctly.




The winner is the first to be arriving on the "Red and Black" final square and who has also responded right to three questions from a single trivia card.

119739.name: Mic Mac Mots
119739.description:
The object of the game is to be the first player or the first team to make a word of at least four letters from the letters earned during the tests.

Playing the game:
The player whose turn it is spins the arrow on the wheel, he draws a card corresponding to the area where the arrow has stopped. He reads the instruction corresponding to its level (aloud or in his head by category). Then he turns the hourglass and following the instructions. It shall reply orally.
Player must find words, rimes, make mimes, solve riddels etc.
If he wins his race, he draws a letter in the bag and the wheel goes to the next player. Otherwise, it passes the wheel to his left to draw no letter in the bag.
The first player to find the correct answer earns a letter also.

The game ends when one player has formed a word
of at least 4 letters.

119740.description:
These three special cards add variety and challenge to any Thunderstone game.

Thornwood Forest: This setting card lightens up levels two and three of the dungeon hall but makes village cards scarcer.
Void Apocalypse: This Hydra Dragon doesn't think much of copycats.
Guardian of Revenge: This Guardian doesn't let you leave the dungeon.

Find dividers for these cards in the Dragonspire boxed set.

NOTE: These three cards are also included within Thunderstone: Werewolf Promo Pack.
119740.name: Thunderstone: Vicious Promo Pack
boardgameexpansion: Thunderstone
Thunderstone: Dragonspire

119741.name: Mon quotidien
119741.description:
Players are journalists and write a newspaper

By answering questions correctly, player draws a cards in the pocket to fill the place on his newspaper. The first player to have completed his newspaper is the winner.

Using the plate divided into several zones, you spin the arrow, and you pull the card corresponding to the area where the arrow is stopped.

There are several type of cards:
- INTERVIEW is a collective issue, the first to answer draws a card from the pouch.
- INTERVIEW PHOTO is a collective issue, but the question is about the photo visible to all players. The first to answer draws a card from the pouch.
- EXPERT is an individual matter. The player whose turn is must answer and draws a card in the pouch for good responders.
- OPPORTUNITY allows to draw a card from the pocket, without having to answer a question.
- BAD LUCK forced the player to deliver one of his cards in the pocket.
- SCOOP is to get a card in an opponent's cards.
- INTERNET cards are optional, as they require an internet connection, to monitor response. If used, they are incorporated in the stack of cards interview.

119742.name: Tatouvu?
119742.description:
There are many details on the game boards.
Players spin the spinner and the arrow show tells you what to look for: a character with glasses, a striped object, (the back) is something that can run, is something that can be eaten etc.
Player who first find it scores a point.

Player with the most points at the end of the game is the winner.

119743.name: Mark Davis Pro Bass Challenge
119743.description:
Mark Davis Pro Bass Challenge is an arcade-style Bass fishing game that allows players to experience true Bass tournaments in a 3-D graphics format, the AI written to simulate actual Black Bass allowing for realistic gameplay.

The various tournaments are designed to follow the official rules, schedules and rating system of true American Bass Fishing tournaments. The gameplay is focused on winning matches and allowing the user to work their way up to the top, gathering equipment and rankings along the way, and compete against the fisher himself, Mark Davis. It is the sequel to Mark Davis' The Fishing Master for Super Nintendo Entertainment System.

Source: Wikipedia, "Mark Davis Pro Bass Challenge", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

119744.name: Mary-Kate and Ashley: Sweet 16
videogameversion: North American Game Boy Advance edition
119744.description:
Mary-Kate and Ashley Olsen have decided they want their 'sweet 16' birthday to be the best! They gather their two close friends and instruct them to go around town and pick up as many friends as possible, and the one who does is the winner of their little game. The game plays out on two levels. In the first, players advance from space to space along a board game track. Each space has a mini-game which requires the players to ride ATVs, jet skis, cars, go rock climbing, or perform other adventure related tasks. Successfully completing the games will allow a player to pick up friends and eventually win the game.

There are four players your can choose from, each with respected colors, including Mary-Kate, Ashley, Claire and Tiffany (blue, red, yellow and green, respectfully.) At the beginning of the game, each player picks which character they want to be, and a number wheel of one to ten is spun for each. The player stops the wheel whenever they choose, and highest number gets to play first, second highest plays next etc. You are in a car that is your avatar's respected color and for the first round, you move as many spaces as your number wheel stopped on. (For each level, you spin the number wheel again.) The kind of marker you land on in the road could signify many different events. The winner of each events gets a certain number of coins which can be used to buy things like gas, if needed.

Single Player Challenge- only the player in the car gets to play a game, randomly chosen (though in some cases, what you see around the car gives hints to what game you're getting. For example, if your car parks next to the ocean with canoes in the water, you have a higher chance of getting a rafting game.)

Multi-player Challenge- Same as the single player, but this time you could play with one, two, or all the other players. The teams are divided at random, but for certain games (like tag) it might be 3 against one, so the player who landed on the marker is the 1 against the other 3.

'Bad' Events- Any number of 'bad' events can occur to the player. You can get sent back on the board however many spaces you roll on the number wheel, there can be an earthquake, roadblock, your car breaks down, or you loose a friend out of your car.

Pick Up a Friend- The closest friend on the sidewalk will get into your car with you. Adding friends can normally make any player first place if you have more. The player can add up to three friends in their car, but these friends do not help with challenges and can leave the car if a 'bad' event occurs.

At the end of the game, the player who has the most coins and picked up the most friends is the winner, regardless of who actually makes it to the finish line first.

Source: Wikipedia, "Mary-Kate and Ashley: Sweet 16", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

119745.name: Space: 1889 - Schnellstartregeln & Abenteuer
119745.description:
user summary

This is a kickstart booklet for the new German edition of Space: 1889 featuring the Ubiquity Roleplaying System.
It contains a short background of the setting, the basic rules and a short adventure set on Mars as well as several pregenerated characters.

119746.name: Fastaval 1986-2011
rpgcategory: Non-Rankable Item (item will not show in the rankings)
119746.description:
This booklet is a celebration of 25 years of Fastaval.

From the homepage:

"Fastaval is the largest role-playing game convention in Denmark. Every extended Easter weekend 400-600 people of all ages gather to play all kinds of games and meet old friends. Fastaval has through 25 years established itself as one of the most important conventions for role-playing in Denmark, Scandinavia, even the world. It is a creative melting-pot for new ideas for games of any kind, as well as the place to enjoy more traditional gaming experiences."

Read more about the convention see the Weblink below

119747.name: Sonic Adventure 2
videogameversion: Japanese Dreamcast (Sonic the Hedgehog Birthday) edition
videogamefranchise: Player's Choice (Best Selling Nintendo Games, US & EU)
119747.description:
The single player mode can be played between two parallel story lines, the "Hero" story mode and the "Dark" story mode. The player has the option of advancing in either story at any time. The "Hero" story features Sonic, Knuckles, Tails, while the "Dark" story features Shadow, Rouge, and Dr. Eggman. Each dark character plays similarly to its corresponding hero character, respectively. Levels advance in the same order for both story lines.

Levels featuring Sonic or Shadow are regular platform levels, designed in much the same way as Sonic's levels in Sonic Adventure.The player's primary objective is to reach the end of the level. Levels with Tails or Dr. Eggman are based on shooting, allowing the player to control a mechanized robot walker and shoot their way to the end. The Knuckles and Rouge levels are based on hunting, with the characters scouring the levels for three keys.

A two-player mode is also available in Sonic Adventure 2, where the corresponding characters from the "Hero" and "Dark" stories are able to play against one another in racing levels, shooting levels, and treasure-hunting levels.

Source: Wikipedia, "Sonic Adventure 2", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

---

From the back of the box

There is a new threat to civilisation, even more powerful than the infamous Dr Eggmann, an immortal capable of overthrowing Sonic for good, his name... Shadow the Hedgehog. With the help of his dark allies, our Sonic look-alike is causing unimaginable destruction, has Sonic met his match? In the most thrilling Sonic adventure ever created, featuring a host of Nintendo Gamecube exclusive enhancements, you decide the outcome - choose to join the dark side and conquer the world or join Sonic, overcome this new evil reign and restore peace to the galaxy.

119748.name: The Oerth Journal (Issue 26 - Oct 2011)
rpgissuearticle: Beyond the Flanaess : Bounds of Oerth
Beyond the Flanaess : Creatures of the Verdured Heights
Beyond the Flanaess : Fireland, Scar The Isle of Razic’Jewel
Beyond the Flanaess : The Land of Blindvidr
Shadowed Paths to Oblivion, Part 1 of 3: Dimensions Lost
119748.description: Volume II, Issue 26. Cover by Daniel Kvasznicza.

119749.name: Heroes of Heirandos
119749.description:
Publisher's blurb:


The great city of Heirandos, the jewel of Meridia awaits you!


The Heroes of Heirandos is a short Labyrinth Lord adventure for 1st or 2nd level adventurers. It introduces the PCs to the Ebonyr Campaign setting. This urban adventure is a springboard for the GM to introduce the PCs to a large city. Including a half dozen encounters, location maps, and random city encounters, Heroes of Heirandos can easily be customized to fit into any campaign setting.

119750.name: Megafortress: Operation Sledgehammer
119750.description:
Back of Box

Shadows in the silent hangar stretched hundreds of feet, cutting huge black angles across the cracked concrete floor. Lieutenant General Bradley Elliott, USAF, stood facing the two Iranians in the dim yellow light cast by a single old work lamp. The air reeked of oil and desert dust.

The sweating cabinet minister mopped his forehead and spoke rapidly in Farsi to his interpreter, a young, tired-looking woman. She turned nervously toward Elliott. "The minister asks if you have brought the 'potk'...the 'sledgehammer' spoken of by your ambassador in Kuwait City?"

"Tell the minister that we are prepared to carry out our part of the bargain if we receive the data we require." Elliott's voice rasped in low tones through the hot air of the darkened hangar. "We want to see your government secure against the extremists in your army. But we need locations and specs on certain targets to finalize our work."

The minister and his aide spoke together for a strained moment. She turned again to Elliott. "The minister is concerned also about the Libyan terrorist machine. He says the training camps and factories and supplies must be stopped also, or his coalition will be... destabilized?"

"We already have made plans to deal with that situation," said the general grimly.

A sound broke the stillness, in darkness a couple of hundred feet behind Elliott's left shoulder--a soft hiss and dull clank, as though a hydraulic door were being closed and latched. Elliott didn't move.

Reluctantly, the minister pulled a folder filled with loose documents from his robes and handed it to Elliott. "He says that he will die if these are discovered missing, and prays that you safeguard them," said the woman. Elliott half-smiled to himself in the darkness. "Ma'am, you tell him it's safe with me." As if by signal, a Kuwaiti lieutenant materialized out of the shadows and the two visitors were ushered out.

Elliott turned as the lights came up. He looked at the monster slowly appearing where the shadows had been, its heavily loaded wings drooping slightly at the tips. He smiled, "Potk, huh? As good a description as any, I guess."

Features:


25 New missions in Iran and Libya, with over 1000 square miles of new territory, threats and targets to master.



New enemy targets include terrorist training camps, port facilities, chemical weapons and nuclear research facilities, ships, submarines, oil storage depots and more.



Megafortress ordnance now includes the CBU-95 FAE (fuel air explosive) and Penguin Mk 3 anti-ship missile.



New enemy naval weapons platforms include guided missile destroyers, frigates, and fast attack craft.



New enemy airborne weapons platforms include MIG-25s and Mirage F-1s.



New enemy SAMs include the SA-10 "Grumble", SA-12A "Gladiator", SM-1 MR, and the Hawk.

119751.name: Ballance
119751.description:
User Summary

Similar to Marble Madness, this game will have you balancing a ball through several levels. Change the ball's density allowing it to float or sink in order to finish the level.

119752.name: Megafortress Mega Pak
119752.description:
Back of the Box

Big, bad, and armed to the teeth!

Megafortress is more than just a battle-scarred B-52. It's the enemy's worst nightmare: a nearly-invisible attacker, carrying enough firepower to destroy the most heavily defended installations in the world.

Forget the run-of-the-flight simulators you're familiar with. Megafortress is in a class by itself: a radically modified B-52H Stratofortress, with radar-absorbing fibersteel skin, an SST nose, and enough state-of-the-art sensing apparatus and weapons systems to jam and blast its way into any place on Earth.

It's a huge, complex aircraft that demands attention to a dizzying array of tasks. Want to know what it's like to deliver 200 tons of mayhem and destruction into the blazing heart of the Iraqi war machine, all the while trying to keep your location a secret? This is the reality of long-range strategic air assault today.

You're not just a Pilot, responsible for takeoff and landing, mid-air refueling and other basic maneuvers. As Navigator you'll plot courses across Iraq and the USSR, keeping your missions on track; as Electronic Warfare Officer you're glued to a radar scope, hunting for threats, jamming signals, keeping the aircraft hidden; as Offensive Weapons Officer you have massive firepower at your disposal: air-to-air missiles, anti-radar missiles, and air mine rockets for defense, and powerful TV/infrared guided glide bombs for the final attack.

With missions in the Persian Gulf and USSR designed by Dale Brown, B-52 navigator and best-selling author, Megafortress is an adventure into the complex world of strategic air assault.

Features


Multi-position bomber simulation with Pilot, Copilot, Navigator, Electronic Warfare Officer, and Offensive Weapons stations.



Complete electronic countermeasures maximize the "stealthiness" of the Megafortress.



Multiple missions in the Desert Storm theater of Iraq/Kuwait, the eastern USSR, and the USAF Red Flag training area in Nevada.



Arsenal includes the latest in air-to-air and air-to-ground missiles, anti-radar missiles, air mine rockets, standard high-explosive "iron" bombs, and TV/infrared glide bombs.



Terrain guidance radar screens operate at realtime speed.



Full 256 color VGA graphics in a 3D world with universal camera angles.



Sound Blaster and AdLib sound support.



Includes 31 missions.


Operation Sledgehammer

A group of extremists in the Iranian army, backed by Libya and led by a power-hungry general, is threatening to overthrow the moderate Iranian government. The Megafortress must defeat the rebels and put an end to Libya's ambitions in the Persian Gulf. Targets include terrorist training camps, bases, ports, and oil depots, weapons research and storage facilities, ships, submarines, and more. Includes 25 missions in the Iranian and Libyan theaters.

Mission Editor

Design your own missions with the Megafortress 3D editor! The 3D editor enables you to create new missions or modify existing Megafortress missions in all Megafortress Theaters. Change the original ordinance loadout for any mission. Landscape your new missions with mountains, radar, enemy interceptors, and more! Add new and varied Megafortress targets. Describe your missions in great detail and create the ultimate Megafortress challenge.

119753.name: Havana 1953
119753.description:
From the publisher's download page description:

Mix rum and revolution in equal parts. Add a splash of espionage and shake well and you’ve got Havana 1953, the Playset of the Month for February [2012]!


Cuba, 1953. Havana has been called "the sexiest city in the world" and for good reason. The rhythm of the night is fueled by the rhumba beat, cocaine and the dazzling stars of Cuba. The Mob is starting to move in and light up the casinos, flush with easy money and easier dupes. General Batista’s government rules with an iron fist behind the scenes. All the glamour of Miami only 90 miles away and with none of the rules. So why are there armed bands in the hills led by obscure guerrillas like Fidel Castro and Che Guevara?


This is another great historical playset written by Chris Bennett, and pairs nicely with Los Angeles 1936 and Dallas 1963.

119754.name: Frost Devils
119754.description:
Publisher's blurb:


Nome, Alaska, 1901. There's a gold rush on at the very end of the Earth, attracting every manner of ne'er-do-well and fiend from deranged Kuskokwagmiut to Wyatt Earp. And you, of course.


Frost Devils is a reskinning of Matt Snyder's excellent game Dust Devils. It can also serve as a really solid and historically meticulous resource guide to Nome at the turn of the last century for any game.

119755.name: Tekken Advance
videogameversion: North American Game Boy Advance edition
119755.description:
User Summary

Tekken Advance represents the debut of the Tekken series on Game Boy. The game, which was roughly contemporary to Tekken Tag Tournament, focused on giving the player a portable experience with their favorite Tekken characters, featuring Hwoarang, Heihachi, Paul Phoenix, Forrest Law, Jin Kazama, and others. Like other Tekken games, the action centers around the Arcade mode, but also features some two-player modes and a "Tag" battle mode where the player and his team of three fight other teams of three until they are defeated.

119756.name: American Illuminati
119756.description:
Though the real history of how the Old World powers spread their influence and came to dominate the USA will never be known, American Illuminati gives you the opportunity to demonstrate how, as the leader of one of these old world dynasties, you would have accomplished the feat.

You will become the leader of an ancient Illuminati faction. Your objective is to infiltrate agents into the newly forming United States in order to exert control over the state governments. The more states you control, the greater your power in the federal government. The more control you have in the federal government the more power you have to dominate the world.

AI is a Euro-style board game that plays equally well with 2, 3 or 4 players. The mechanics are simple enough that you can teach most anyone to play, though strategic players are much more likely to win.

Each player is attempting to place agents into the newly forming USA. The more states your faction controls during the four major turning points in 19th century US history, the more conspiracy cards you will draw. Conspiracy cards can be used to gain advantages during the game but are also how you win the game.The Conspiracy Deck mimics a standard deck of playing cards though all the suites are different to fit the Illuminati theme. Throughout the game you are secretly attempting to form the best Poker hand (what's more American than Poker?) with your Conspiracy Cards while playing your Action Cards to maximum advantage.

119757.name: Aussie Footy
119757.description:
A recreation of Australian Rules Football using a Tiddlywink mechanic. Players assume the role of the 18th player and move the football to images of the 17 other players on the board. The player retains possession as long as the football is "kicked" to an image of their player who is deemed to have caught or "marked" the ball. If the football falls on the picture of an opposing player or in an open field, the opponent takes control of the ball. Wooden goalposts at each end signify the goalposts and a player can either secure a goal (6 points) or behind (1 point), depending on the accuracy of their aim.

The football has a red and blue side, and if the ball goes off the board ("out of bounds"), it is flipped and whatever colour lands face-up gains possession. When a football equally sits on a red and blue player, the colour that is face-up determines which player has possession. Flipping is also used to determine who kicks the ball first at the commencement of the game or after a goal is scored.

The winner can be determined by the first to reach a pre-determined number of points, or using an elapsed amount of time.

The game first came out during the late 1960s.

119758.name: Game Geek (Issue 26 - Feb 2012)
rpgissuearticle: Behind the Game - Magic: The Gathering
119758.description:
Table of Contents

Musing of the Avalon Stogie
Behind the Game - Magic
Coral Throne - Interlude XVII
Eternal Cycle Excerpt
Avalon Pathfinder
Multi-Verse
Dept 13 Comic, Issue #11
Artist Spotlight
Battle Axe
Avalon Models
Arcana
Reviews
Cool Stuff
What's New
Free Stuff

119759.name: Petrol
119759.description:
Magnetic game in which the purpose is to obtain a capital superior to that of the opponents by extracting the most amount of oil.

Players are represented by 4 Disney characters who try to get rich in this Monopoly style game with a cute oil rig miniature which moves due to a magnet secretly located under the board whenever the players choose to dig for oil in the right spot.

Contents: Board with a trigger tied to 3 magnets located underneath, 4 Disney characters, banknotes, 8 building concession cards, 36 right to drill cards, oil deposits plastic pawns in 2 colors, magnetic oil rig miniature, 2 dice, rules.

videogame: Star Wars Galaxies: The Complete Online Adventures
Star Wars Galaxies: The Total Experience
119760.name: Star Wars Galaxies: Jump to Lightspeed
videogameexpansion: Star Wars Galaxies: An Empire Divided
videogamehonor: 2005 D.I.C.E. Massively Multiplayer Game of the Year Nominee
videogamecompilation: Star Wars Galaxies: The Complete Online Adventures
Star Wars Galaxies: The Total Experience
119760.description:
The struggle between the Galactic Empire and the Rebel Alliance extends into space with Star Wars Galaxies: Jump to Lightspeed, the first expansion for the award-winning Massively Multiplayer Online Role-Playing game set in the Star Wars universe. This addition dramatically expands the Star Wars Galaxies franchise by providing players more than 15 different vehicles for space exploration and combat.

Starfighters and other starships in the expansion can be used for both space exploration and combat, allowing players to join up with allies and fly familiar X-wings and TIE fighters into battle against faction-aligned opponents and AI-controlled ships. Transport ships similar to the well-known Millennium Falcon are included, allowing players to venture through space with friends aboard.

Set in the Star Wars timeframe between Episode IV and Episode V, this first extension to the Star Wars Galaxies foundation opens 10 vast and distinct space sectors, spanning from the Core Worlds to the Outer Rim, for players to explore while engaging their opponents in intense real-time combat or uniting with friends in battle or exploration. Players can embark on more than 100 new missions, venturing through asteroid fields, nebulae and space junkyards while honing skills in four new space-specific professions. The game also features two new and completely customizable species.

Since its launch in June 2003, Star Wars Galaxies has allowed players to live the Star Wars saga and become immersed in the classic Star Wars universe simultaneously. Star Wars Galaxies: Jump to Lightspeed continues the full immersion in the greatest Star Wars saga ever told: Yours.
Product Description
Star Wars Galaxies: Jump To Lightspeed offers intense, real-time space combat that expands on the original role-playing game. Set in the time period between Episodes IV and V, this incredible expansion will take players through space as they become involved with either the Rebel Alliance or The Empire. Work alone to discover untold legends in the Star Wars Galaxy! Over 100 thrilling new missions waiting for you, as you fly across nebulae, space junkyards and asteroid fields

Source: The Publisher Website.

videogame: Star Wars Galaxies: The Complete Online Adventures
119761.name: Star Wars Galaxies: Trials of Obi-Wan
videogameexpansion: Star Wars Galaxies: An Empire Divided
videogamecompilation: Star Wars Galaxies: The Complete Online Adventures
119761.description:
User Summary

Trials of Obi-Wan is an expansion to the MMORPG, Star Wars Galaxies. You can follow Obi-Wan's path to Mustafar and play through more than 50 new missions.

videogame: Star Wars Galaxies: The Complete Online Adventures
119762.name: Star Wars Galaxies: Episode III Rage of the Wookiees
videogameexpansion: Star Wars Galaxies: An Empire Divided
videogamecompilation: Star Wars Galaxies: The Complete Online Adventures
119762.description:
User Summary

Star Wars Galaxies: Episode III Rage of the Wookiees is an expansion to Star Wars Galaxies and features new quests and a new adventure planet, Kashyyyk.

119763.description:
What else could deliver a +28 bite attacks for 50 magic damage? And a +26 claw attack? The Colossal Red Dragon releases this month, and we have a larger pic to share of the beast.

There is a double-sided full-color map and a playable game scenario to really get the battle going. Like all the figures in the D&D Icons line, this Red Dragon is playable in both the D&D Miniatures skirmish game and any roleplaying campaign.

Awards
2007 Origins Award for Miniature or Miniatures Line, Colossal Red Dragon

Contents:
One pre-painted red dragon (6"x6" base)
Double-sided stat card
Playable encounter
Full-color poster map
Measures approximatley 14" tall
In scale to other D&D Miniatures
Limited Edition
119763.name: D&D Miniatures Icons: Colossal Red Dragon
boardgameexpansion: Dungeons & Dragons Miniatures

119764.name: Oil Tycoon
119764.description:
User Summary

This strategy game lets you take charge of a lucrative oil refining operation.

119765.name: Microsoft Flight Simulator 2000
videogamehonor: 2000 D.I.C.E. Simulation Game of the Year Winner
119765.description:
User Summary

Microsoft Flight Simulator 2000 is the latest version of Microsoft's highly realistic, graphically advanced flight simulat or, the best-selling PC flight simulation ever produced. Microsoft has worked closely with leaders in the aviation industry: aircr aft manufacturers, training and pilot organizations, data suppliers, and flight instructors to make Flight Simulator 2000 Professi onal Edition as real as it gets.

Flight Simulator 2000 is the civilian flight simulator for the new millennium. Built on a foundation of realism that spans over 17 years, Flight Simulator 2000 is the largest leap forward in Microsoft Flight Simulator history. For the first time ever, we are o ffering a "Professional" Edition of Microsoft Flight Simulator in addition to Flight Simulator 2000. The Professional version of F light Simulator 2000 is geared to Flight Simulator enthusiasts, real pilots, those who want "more features and more content" and t hose who are interested in using Flight Simulator 2000 as a PC-based flight training and proficiency aid.

119766.name: Diner
119766.description:
Box Back

Peter Pepper, the brave chef from BURGERTIME is back! But so are the evil Hot Dogs and some NEW villains - a cheap Cherry, a bad Banana and Mugsy, the Mug o' Root Beer. Peter needs your help to escape these Rotten Foods and get lunch onto the plate!

119770.name: Exhibit: Artifacts of the Ages
119770.description:
An old, eccentric archeologist has died and his private collection, rich with a variety of artifacts of various types from various Cultures and Eras, is being auctioned off. These artifacts have not yet been assessed, but as a museum curator, you don't want to wait for that - you do your own research and armed with partial information, you bid based on what you think the item's value might be. Once all bids are in, the artifacts will be assessed, and any bid that's higher than the actual value will not be approved by your board of directors! So for each artifact, the highest bid that is not greater than the actual value will win the auction!

Exhibit is a set collection game with an unusual auction mechanism which is akin to multiple simultaneous games of Liar's Dice.

119771.description:
From the Publisher's Site:

Whether you plan on treasure-seeking in the grim darkness or holding back the forces of evil with naught but your sword and your wits, Dwarf King’s Hold is the acclaimed dungeon crawler board game from Mantic Games. Fuelled by action points and dice-driven combat, Dwarf King’s Hold is a objective-led game of skill and cunning, expanded upon by Dwarf King’s Hold: Ancient Grudge:

Make yours Multiplayer: introduces four new scenarios for 3-5 player games.

More Choice: Rules for five new troop choices for each of the factions, - Undead, Dwarf, Elves and Orcs - including special characters and large monsters such as the Werewolf and the troll-like Bogie.

Introducing Warbands: includes point costs for all troop types meaning you can play through all previous scenarios with a Warband of your choice.

New Rooms: includes two new Ice-themed tiles to expand your collection of large rooms.
119771.name: Dwarf King's Hold: Ancient Grudge
boardgameexpansion: Dwarf King's Hold: Dead Rising
Dwarf King's Hold: Green Menace
boardgamepodcastepisode: Meeples & Miniatures - Episode 93 - Dreadball, Part I - Interview with Jake Thornton

119772.name: Alter Ego
119772.description:
A cooperative deck building game of heroism.

You won't see Crime City on any map, but that's how people have come to know your hometown. Sadists, Anarchists, the Mafia, each carving out portions of the city they call their own. Hundreds of innocent bystanders caught up every day in their turf wars, or held under their oppressive thumbs. Precious few have the time, the money, the guts, or the wherewithal to do anything about it. You're one of those few... of course it means you'll have to give up that happy home life, or that cushy job. The paper paints vigilantism in a negative light - you'd be viewed by the community as a monster. But your city bleeds... the city bleeds and it calls your name. Will you answer?

You're a vigilante hero, one of the few in Crime City who have come together to put an end to the reign of terror the city's been trapped under. Banding together, you'll fight through a swath of henchmen in order to find and defeat several Arch Villains. But as you get stronger as a hero, you'll have to neglect some parts of your Alter Ego life - your family, your job, and the community.

Each turn you'll play a certain number of cards, and each turn you'll add 1 new card to your deck. Job, Community, and Family cards give you benefits, but in order to fight crime you'll need to play Hero cards instead. As the game goes on, which aspect of your Alter Ego life will you neglect?

While Alter Ego is a cooperative game, there may be a competitive aspect (or mode) as well. In addition to defeating Arch Villains, each player has their own private Nemesis which they need to defeat in order to win the game.

119773.name: Dice Works
119773.description:
Players race to complete inventions by drafting dice in real time. Build your inventions by grabbing the correct dice... you can draft dice for later by placing it in your scrapyard, but it's not as efficient that way.

Dice Works is a real-time dice drafting game. A number of dice are rolled into the center of the table, and players grab them - one at a time, using only 1 hand - and place them on their player board in an effort to fill up the boxes with the correct assortment of colors. A round ends when all of the dice have been drafted, and players advance their workers into boxes that have been completed.

Players can 'scrap' multiple dice of a single color to create any die they want of that color. The further your workers are advanced, the more efficiently you can scrap.

The winner is the first player to get a worker to the top of 1 (2 on the advanced board) column, finishing an invention!

This game might turn into a spinoff using the dice from Tasty Minstrel Games' Martian Dice game.

119774.name: UFO!
119774.description:
From the box:

You're in command of an Earth Federation robot-controlled battle cruiser. Your mission is to protect earth from endless swarms of Unidentified Flying Objects! You're armed with laser cannon and protected by an energized force field...but beware of what appear to be light-speed Starships armed with computer-guided missiles!

119775.name: Motocross (Intellivision)
119775.description:
Back of Box

Speeding up the long straights, blasting through tight S turns, or hurling across wild jumps, you're meant to eat dirt and claim victory! What a racing bike you've got! The competition is fierce, the terrain is rough. Challenge your toughest adversary, then leave him behind, as you cross the finish line!

119776.name: Thunderball!
119776.description:
From the box:

A wildly realistic pinball game! Thunderball has all the action including thumper bumpers, digital scoring and unique shifting flippers you can move to cover additional area.

119777.name: Casino Slot Machine!
119777.description:
From the box:

Lady Luck is alive and well and living inside this authentic computerized simulation of the latest nine window one armed bandits. Enter your bets into the computer and pull the handle. You can win (or lose) in five different directions on each turn.

119778.name: Commodore 16
119778.description:
The Commodore 16 was a home computer made by Commodore with a 6502-compatible 8501 CPU, released in 1984. It was intended to be an entry-level computer to replace the VIC-20 and it often sold for 99 USD. A cost-reduced version, the Commodore 116, was sold only in Europe.

Outwardly the C16 resembled the VIC-20 and the C64, but with a dark gray case and light gray keys. The keyboard layout differed slightly from the earlier models, adding an escape key and four cursor keys replacing the shifted-key arrangement inherited from the C-64 and VIC. Performance-wise located between the VIC-20 and 64, it had 16 kilobytes of RAM with 12 KB available to its built-in BASIC interpreter, and a new sound and video chipset offering a palette of 128 colors (in reality 121, since the system had a 16 base colors and 8 shades but black always remained black, with all 8 shades), the TED (better than the VIC used in the VIC-20, but lacking the sprite capability of the VIC-II and advanced sound capabilities of the SID, both used in the C64). The ROM resident BASIC 3.5, however, was more powerful than the VIC-20's and C64's BASIC 2.0, in that it had commands for sound and bitmapped graphics (320×200 pixels), as well as simple program tracing/debugging.

The C16 was a flop in the US and was discontinued within a year, but it sold reasonably well in Europe as a low-end game machine (over 90% of all C16 software was produced by European developers) and in Mexico as well.

Source: Wikipedia, "Commodore 16", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

119779.name: Commodore Plus/4
119779.description:
The Commodore Plus/4 was a home computer released by Commodore International in 1984. The "Plus/4" name refers to the four-application ROM resident office suite (word processor, spreadsheet, database, and graphing); it was billed as "the productivity computer with software built-in". It had some success in Europe, though it was a total flop in the United States.

The TED offered 121-color (15 colors × 8 luminance levels + black) video, a palette matched only by Atari Computers at the time, and 320×200 video resolution, which was standard for computers intended to be capable of connecting to a television. The Plus/4's memory map gave it a larger amount of user-accessible memory than the C64, and its BASIC programming language was vastly improved, adding sound and graphics commands as well as looping commands that improved program structure. Commodore released a high-speed floppy disk drive for the Plus/4, the Commodore 1551, which offered much better performance than the C64/1541 combination because it used a parallel interface rather than a serial bus. However, the Plus/4 did not have the parallel interface built-in; it was provided by a plug-in cartridge supplied with the drive.

Unlike the C64 which emulated the 6551 chip in software, the Plus/4 had a built-in MOS Technology 6551 UART chip that could perform up to 19200 bit/s. This allowed the Plus/4 to use high-speed modems without additional hardware or software tricks (the C64 required specially written software to operate at 2400 bit/s). But most people could only afford 300- or 1200-bit/s modems in 1984—and Commodore never released a 2400-bit/s modem—so this feature went largely unnoticed. The Plus/4 keyboard had a separately placed directional "diamond" of four cursor keys, presumably more intuitive to use than the VIC's and C64's two shifted cursor keys. A reset button was added on the right side of the system, a feature lacking on the C-64. Also, for serious programmers, the Plus/4 featured a ROM-resident machine code monitor, which rekindled a tradition from the first Commodore computers.

Source: Wikipedia, "Commodore Plus/4", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

119780.name: VIC-20
119780.description:
The VIC-20 (Germany: VC-20; Japan: VIC-1001) is an 8-bit home computer which was sold by Commodore Business Machines.

The VIC-20 had proprietary connectors for program/expansion cartridges and a tape drive (PET-standard Datassette). It came with 5 kB RAM, but 1.5& kB was used by the system for various things, like the video display (which had a rather unusual 22×23 char/line screen layout), and other dynamic aspects of the ROM-resident BASIC interpreter and KERNAL (a low-level operating system). Thus, 3583 bytes of BASIC program memory for code and variables was available to the user of an unexpanded machine.

The computer also had a serial bus (a serial version of the PET's IEEE-488 bus) for daisy chaining disk drives and printers; a TTL-level "user port" with both RS-232 and Centronics signals (most frequently used as RS-232, for connecting a modem); and a single DE-9 game controller port, compatible with the digital joysticks and paddles used with Atari 2600 videogame consoles and, later, the C64 (the use of a standard port ensured ample supply of Atari-manufactured and other third-party joysticks; Commodore itself offered an Atari-protocol joystick under the Commodore brand).

Importantly, like most video game consoles and many computers at the time the VIC had a cartridge port to allow for plug-in cartridges with games and other software as well as for adding memory to the machine. Port expander boxes were available from Commodore and other vendors to allow more than one cartridge to be attached at a time. Cartridge software ranged from 4-16k in size, although the latter was uncommon due to its cost and only larger software houses produced 16k cartridges.

The graphics capabilities of the VIC chip (6560/6561) were limited but flexible. At startup the screen showed 176 x 184 pixels, with a fixed-colour border to the edges of the screen; since an NTSC or PAL screen has a 4:3 width-to-height ratio, each VIC pixel was much wider than it was high. The screen normally showed 22 columns and 23 rows of 8-by-8-pixel characters; it was possible to increase these dimensions but the characters would soon run out the sides of the monitor. Like on the PET, 256 different characters could be displayed at a time, normally taken from one of the two character generators in ROM (one for upper-case letters and simple graphics, the other for mixed-case—non-English characters were not provided). Normally, the VIC-20 was operated in high-resolution mode whereby each character was 8x8 pixels in size and used one color. A lower-resolution multicolor mode could also be used with 4x8 characters and three colors each, but it was not used as often due to its extreme blockiness.

Source: Wikipedia, "Commodore VIC-20", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

119781.description:
Legacy: Gears of Time is a strategic card game, mechanically rooted in its time travel theme. Players each play cards from their own hand, draw from a central draw pile, move and play technologies on a single timeline, while placing their influence cubes on existing technologies.

Legacy is played on a timeline that grows at the end of each of 4 rounds. Players take turns during a round consisting of 3 actions each. During each turn, you may travel back in time, play a technology card from your hand, influence an existing technology, or draw two cards (keeping only one).

As you travel back in time, Technologies are played from your hand by paying their discard cost. Any technologies you play generate influence for you automatically.

Having more influence than your opponents is the key to claiming rewards for a technology! At the end of each round, rewards are given for each technology and its dependencies. One Influence cube from each technology will come off at the end of each round, forming your influence pool to be used in future rounds to influence existing technologies. Keep in mind, a technology is only considered successful if all of its dependencies exist previously on the timeline.

Since there are several copies of each technology, you may be able to preempt and eliminate an existing copy by playing yours earlier in the timeline! Be sure there is room for your new technology, though; each time-frame has a capacity equal to it's distance from the present.

There are also a few rare but powerful Fate cards, each allowing you to break the rules in interesting ways. Fate cards have no discard cost and don't require an action to be played.

By strategically influencing existing technologies, adapting to your opponents actions, and carefully choosing when to go further back in time, you will find yourself victorious over your rivals! History remains intact until the Ancient Machine demands you return to the past to rebuild history, and your Legacy, once more.

Summary:

4 Rounds
4 Turns per Round
3 Actions per Turn (any mix of the following):
Travel back in Time
Play a Technology card
Influence an existing Technology
Draw two cards (keep one)
119781.name: Legacy: Gears of Time
boardgameexpansion: Legacy: Forbidden Machines
Legacy: Forbidden Machines – Deep Vault

Legacy: Gears of Time – Kickstarter Backer Promo Card
Legacy: Gears of Time – Mini-Expansion

Episode 51 - Future Time
The One About a Little "Guy Time"

119782.description:
Paiko is a one-on-one turn based strategy game optimized to cater to intuitive players.

The board and tiles have a Japanese block art aesthetic, which has been cast into black and white for the convenience of print and play. Everything needed to play is provided on our website.

In Paiko, your main objective is to spread out your tiles and block off your opponent's -- capturing your opponent's tiles is a pleasant secondary objective.

You win Paiko by getting 10 points, and you amass points by positioning your tiles in aggressive places on the board. You gain:
0 points for tiles in the safety of your own homeground
1 point for tiles in the even-footed middle ground
2 points for tiles in your opponent's homeground.

On your turn, you can choose to do one of three things: place a tile on the board, move a tile already on the board, or draw 3 more tiles of your choosing. You start the game with a hand of 8 tiles (if white), or 10 tiles (if black). Because Paiko has 8 kinds of tiles, much strategy is involved in choosing your starting hand, and choosing when to spend time building your hand by drawing tiles.
119782.name: Paiko

119785.name: Thorwal Standard (Issue 6 - Sep 1996)
119785.description: This issue contains the 2nd part of the adventure "Die Statue von Talun" and the short scenario "Der dritte Mann"

119786.name: Thorwal Standard (Issue 5 - Mar 1996)
119786.description: This issue contains the adventure "Das Ende eines Sommers" and the short adventure "Koboldspiel"

119787.name: Thorwal Standard (Issue 4 - Oct 1995)
119787.description: This issue contains the adventure "Ein reines Zeitproblem" and the adventure "Sturmvögel"

boardgamehonor: 2014 Golden Geek Best Strategy Board Game Nominee
2015 International Gamers Award - General Strategy: Multi-player Nominee
119788.description:
The mythical realm of Hyperborea was ruled by an ancient civilization that used magical crystals as their main source of energy. With time, the Hyperboreans became greedy, and their search for power in the deep made the crystals unstable, causing earthquakes, mutations, droughts and floods. Hyperboreans just dug deeper, and only a few wise mages, foreseeing the inevitable, built an unbreakable magical barrier. When the unharnessed magical energy was unleashed from the deep, the Hyperborean civilization was destroyed in a single day, only the magical barrier preventing the disappearance of life from the whole land. The survivors living in the small outposts outside Hyperborea were now sealed out by the barrier. The knowledge of crystals was declared forbidden it was because too dangerous, or simply forgotten.

Over centuries, six rival realms were born from the ashes of the Hyperborean civilization: the militarist Red Duchy; the Emerald Kingdom and its death-delivering archers; the Purple Matriarchy fanatically worshipping the goddess of life; the skilled diplomats and merchants of the Golden Barony; the Coral Throne with its efficiently organized society and finally the secluded and enigmatic Celestial Reign.

The fragile peace between the different realms was not intended to last. One day, the magical barrier suddenly collapsed. A whole new land stood in front of the six kingdoms, still haunted by the old Hyperboreans turned into harmless but ominous ghosts, full of ruins to discover and cities to explore. Each realm is now sending its best warriors and explorers to Hyperborea in order to achieve dominance over their rivals, but which will prevail? Brutal strength or deep understanding of science? The discovery of valuable artifacts in the lost ruins or the retaking of long, lost cities? Only you, as the leader of one of the factions, can lead your people to the ultimate dominance over Hyperborea!

Set in a mythical land of the same name, Hyperborea is a light civilization game for 2 to 6 players that takes 20-25 minutes per player. The game begins at the time when the magic barrier protecting access to the mythical continent of Hyperborea suddenly falls.

Each player takes the role of the leader of a small kingdom situated just outside the now open to be conquered and explored land. Her kingdom has limited knowledge of housing, trade, movement, warfare, research, and growth, but new and exciting powers are hidden in Hyperborea. During the game, this kingdom will grow in numbers and raise armies, extend its territory, explore and conquer, learn new technologies, etc...

The game's main mechanism, which can be described as "bag-building", involves you building a pool of "civilicubes". Each cube represents specializations for your kingdom: war, trade, movement, building, knowledge, growth. Grey cubes represent corruption and waste, and players will acquire them by developing new technologies. (Power corrupts by its own definition, and the more complex a society becomes, the more waste it generates.) Each turn, players draw three random cubes from their bags, then use them to activate knowledge (technologies) they own.

119789.description: This issue contains the adventure "Die Götterinsel" and many rule additions.

119790.name: Thorwal Standard (Issue 2 - Mar 1991)
119790.description: This issue contains the adventure "Das geheimnisvolle Buch" and the article with rules for sexual relation "Sex in Aventurien"

119791.name: Weltenbote (Issue 1 - Oct 2006)
119791.description: This issue contains background material for the PROST Worlds Pyramos, Avarion, Parydia and Pentagramm.

119792.description: Edition Wars is a fun-filled, tongue-in-check standalone strategy card game for 3-5 players in which you become a Gamemaster slavishly devoted to your edition of the game! In the effort to champion your edition, you will compete to be the first to assemble a complete group of six Gamers. But this simple task is complicated by the fact that the other Gamemasters are trying to steal your Gamers out from under you! You can respond in kind, defend your existing Gamers with the standard attacks of Snark, Blog, and Merch; as well as equip yourself with special gear and toss about instant critical effects, all of which will aid you on your epic quest to edition supremacy! Let the Edition Wars begin...
119792.name: Edition Wars

119793.description: This issue contains background material and rules for the free RPG worlds: Pyramos, Avarion, Parydia, Esper & Pentagramm.
